Input:It is Friday and Jim is home alone.  He is preparing dinner.  After dinner he sits down to watch television. Input: The following is a list of six statements that describe the six levels of the hierarchy of responsibility.  (There is an alternative to "the ladder of power."  "The ladder of responsibility" is better because it is more accurate.)  1. If a problem occurs at the root (management), then all the workers who work below may be unable to solve the problem and may require that higher management be called to assist.  2. When a higher level of management is involved, all of the workers may experience a decrease in their pay and opportunities.  3. When higher level of management is called in to solve a problem, several workers become affected by the solution and may require compensation. 4. When a solution is achieved, and all of the workers may receive compensation for the cost of labor, a new problem may erupt. 5. When the workers are rewarded when a solution is achieved, they may not work to exceed the level of reward, and in fact may even attempt to limit their level of experience in order to avoid rewards that are too high.  6. When a lower level of management is involved in a problem, the workers may feel that the solution gives them a superior level of status and will encourage them to continue performing with poor effort and poor results.
Output: 6

Input: A farmer wants to be certain which row of corn to plant.  He’ll plant five rows of corn at different locations around the field, and then he will plant two rows of corn at other locations on the same row.  He’d like to have enough corn at each location to harvest at least one bushel of corn that would sell for $4.50 per bushel.  So the farmer wants to plant at least two different locations of corn.  The first location that he plants, is the location where he plants the third row of corn, but he only plants one bushel at each location.  The farmer thinks that he may get two bushels for each of his planted locations, but each location only yields one bushel for each bushel of corn.  So the farmer plans to plant only at least two locations of corn.  Then to ensure that he harvests more than one bushel per row of corn, he’ll plant at least three locations where he plants the first row.  If at least one bushel per row lands in each location of corn, he gets at least 9 bushels per row.  If at most 2 bushels land in each location of corn in that row, then he gets only 4 bushels per row, and therefore doesn’t get enough corn to produce $4.50 per row that sells for $4.50.  What are the values of each of the locations where he plants corn?
Output: 4 x (9 + 2) / 4 = 16

After the match the new friends played a game at the park for an hour and a half.  Zachery was ready to go back home, but John said he couldn’t skate home.  Zachery said that he couldn’t play without John, so John agreed to take him home.  Zachery took his board and skate back home, and he saw that John had skated to his house and was waiting for he and his mother.
After about 20 minutes John got so frustrated with Zachery that he picked Zachery’s skates up and threw them to the ground.  John ran away, because he was tired of sitting at the rink just waiting for Zachery to skate over.  Zachery, being the good friend he was, picked the board up and skated over to find John.
How long did Zachery play with John before John ran away?
Output: 4

Input: A father decides to teach his son, who was born in the 1960s, about the way that a car will be purchased in the 1970s.  The father sets up a loan that will last 70 years.  Every month of the loan period, the son is expected to make a $15 payment to pay off his loan.  If the son is to make that payment, at 10 years of age, there will be 1 year left to pay off the loan.  Assuming $100/year and a $50 loan amount, the final payment will be $1,800 in 1971.  Assuming an interest rate of 8% per year, the interest rate on the loan will be $17,000 in 1970 when the son is 38 years old and when the son is 77 years old, the interest rate will be $15,000.  Assuming an annual interest rate of 2% per year, the cost of paying off the loan will be $5.25 in 1971 and $4.75 in 1979.  If an interest rate of 10% per year is assumed at $3,000, the cost of paying the loan will be $3,000 in 1972 and $2,600 in 1979.  Suppose all the interest is included in the loan amount by calculating at a 7% annual rate.  The son will pay $7,375, and even if he has 5% more income than in 1970, the cost will be the same.  There will be a total of $18,000 in payments that will cause the loan to have a net present value of $15,000.
Output: $500

Input: The following are the rules of the World Series: if there are both a home run and a double play, neither are counted as an infield hit and one of them will be ruled out, as in the strike zone. On the other hand, if a base runner steps on third (including himself), he can be considered safe for home and one out will be counted. Thus, the following are the rules of double plays:  When a man touches home plate, he is forced to stay on the bag and any player on that side has to call out home to the base runner, and anyone running past the out-runner does not have to call this out. Then, once the runner on home plate completes the tag, he is safe for home and one batter will be out. Thus, the following set of rules are the definition of an infield hit when a base runner does not attempt to steal :  A base runner does not have an instant chance to steal second or third if he does not want to;  If he tries to steal second or third immediately after touching home plate, an umpire makes him stay on the bag until he finishes the tag  If he tries to go for third in a hurry, the umpire counts the two out and one of them is allowed on the next pitch as a base hit. Thus, when a base runner touches home plate, it counts as an infield hit and two base hits, including the one out in which he has been forced to stay.
Output: 4

Input: A car breaks down on the side of the road and is towed to the repair shop. On the repair team, the first employee is a mechanic.  The mechanic fixes the car.  When the car is back in operation, the manager asks the mechanic to change a tire.  The mechanic puts the new tire on and drives off to the next job.  After a few minutes his car starts to smoke, so he reaches under the hood and discovers a large amount of black smoke.  He pulls the hood apart to investigate and realizes that two tires, both with bald spots on them, are smoking.  He walks to the other side of the car and discovers a hose attached to the brake pad.  He ties it to his truck and then begins to try to get his car started.  He can’t get the brakes to engage.  The mechanic is stuck.  The mechanic: 1. Pulls the lever to activate the emergency brake and 2. Squints while pressing the lever against the floor. After about 5 minutes of trying to start the car, he decides to cut the wire connecting the brake pads to the engine brake, releasing the pressure on the emergency brake. He gets the engine going again and stops the car.  When he is done, he unplugs the brake and gets out of the car to see if there is anything wrong, but suddenly he feels an electrical surge in his body and his head swamps with sweat.  He falls to the ground in disbelief.  He tries to take his cell phone out of his pocket to see if he is going to get a call, but he gets the signal blocked by his own sweat.  As he continues to stand and walk down the street, he can no longer see any of the pedestrians because of his own sweat and the black smoke.  He then realizes that in the back of his car is the smoke that exploded in his face and he falls facefirst to the ground.  What did the mechanic do next?  Answer the following multiple choice questions in the form supplied below:  • Who in the repair shop was a member of a first-aid squad? • What skills did the employees at the repair shop have? • What did the shop do when the mechanic was having trouble starting the car? • How did his co-workers react?
Output: 36

Input: A woman named Alice is in her room cleaning when Alice receives a phone call from a person named David. David is having trouble with the phone from which he is currently calling Alice. Output: 1300

Solution:

Alice had called the contractor to give her an estimate.  He gave her an hourly rate which was $5, and then gave her a time estimate of 12.  She then told him that she would call him back the next day with the phone.  She then got a callback from him, which she picked up, and then cancelled it to give herself peace of mind.  She called back the next day at 6:30 and they spoke and were able to work it out.  She then wrote a check which she gave to him in the amount of $5.00.  David has now been calling her, but instead of picking up, she has been on hold for over an hour.  She has also canceled all of David’s calls, as she said that she was tired of the calls.  After she gives David a call to come to her house and estimate the damage, she finds that all of the damage is only $400.00.  She then decides that David must be in a hurry to get all of their money.  After a conversation with Alice’s husband that she did not ask for, she says that the estimate was not really a cost estimate, as the contractor had just left the house after talking to Alice about it.  She also says that she wants her money back that he gave her, but David says that he will give her the money to cover the bills that have come in over the past month.  Alice does not want to take any more calls from David and then calls her husband again.  He asks David what happened to their phone, and David says that they sold it. Input: Joe is out working on a ranch.  Joe is a rancher that raises cows for feed.  He had just loaded the cows onto an old tractor when he heard a loud noise.  When people hear loud noises that go above 80 decibels, they usually think it’s the wind.  Joe walked over to the tractor so that he could check the oil and replace the clutch.  He looked at the oil, but it didn’t look any different than it usually did.  Then he went over to the tractor and did some inspection of its parts, and didn’t find anything wrong.  He didn’t check the clutch, but did take a look at the oil.  He was shocked to see that it was totally dry.  He went into the barn and grabbed some oil and started filling up the oil tank to refill the oil, and also filled up the transmission.  Soon after this, the tractor started and ran great!  Joe ran the old tractor for a half mile.  While he was driving it, he discovered that the transmission was not working properly!  He noticed the transmission light was blinking and the transmission was making a strange noise when he tried to start it.  He ran the transmission a few more times.  Then his transmission started making a very peculiar noise when he tried to go up and down hills.  It also seemed like it was in trouble.  While he tried to work the transmission this way and that, it had to be constantly adjusted to keep from slipping or breaking down.  After a few tries, he finally decided that the transmission could not hold up against the weight of the cattle and the farm equipment he was hauling around the ranch.  He figured that if the transmission was not going to last forever, he had better get it over with.  So he got the tractor down to the barn.  Then he started on the back of the old tractor.  Once he got into the tractor, he started shifting the gears and revving things up to try and get the transmission to start.  He tried it all, for about half an hour, when he discovered that there was no oil in the transmission, which meant there was no way the transmission was going to work anymore.  After some coaxing, he was able to get it to start.  He went back to the barn and he pulled some empty milk jugs from the refrigerator.  He started bringing the jugs down the hill.

A

The block in 1999 included a total of 3,737,760 children aged 13–64 who were on SNAP, 2,932,480 who were on Medi/Cal, 14,520 who were on TANf. In 1999, the total child poverty rate was 12.4 percent.
